docs.lead_paragraph: THE CLAIM -- Melatonin can help you conquer jet lag. THE FACTS -- Some bleary-eyed travelers swear by melatonin as a way to beat jet lag. But experts say research on the hormone's effectiveness is far from clear-cut. Over the years, more than a dozen studies have tried to determine whether melatonin can ease symptoms of jet lag by adjusting the body's internal clock to new time zones. Some have shown that it helps in small doses; others have found that it is no better than a placebo.
docs.abstract: Melatonin, although able to help adjust internal body clock, has not been proven to help specifically lessen effects of jet lag on body; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: Experts say research on the hormone's effectiveness as a way to beat jet lag is far from clear-cut.

docs.lead_paragraph: Medical marijuana is now legal in 11 states, and bills to legalize it are pending in at least 7 more. The drug is also at the heart of a case being considered by the United States Supreme Court. Yet there remains much confusion over whether marijuana in fact has any significant medical effect.
docs.abstract: Eleven states have legalized medical marijuana and seven others are considering legislation to allow marijuana use for those suffering variety of illnesses; medical benefits have not been demonstrated and there has been little clinical research done on marijuana, which has been used medically for at least 5,000 years; evidence of harmful effects of marijuana use by young people has been shown in variety of research studies; several people using marijuana for their medical problems describe personal benefits of use (M)
docs.snippet: Despite efforts to legalize medical marijuana, there remains much confusion over whether it in fact has any significant medical effect.

docs.lead_paragraph: The case of Terri Schiavo may help accomplish something that medical experts have been trying to do for years, with scant success: motivate people to tell their families and doctors what treatments they would -- or would not -- want if illness or injury left them unable to make decisions. Ms. Schiavo, 41, severely brain-damaged but kept alive by a feeding tube for 15 years, had no living will or other written statement of her wishes, and she had not authorized anyone to make decisions on her behalf.

headline.main: The Best Way to Keep Control: Leave Instructions

docs.abstract: Case of Terri Schiavo, 41-year-old severely brain-damaged woman who has been center of battle over patient and family rights, has motivated individuals to establish living wills and health care proxies to avoid similar situation; Dr Arthur Caplan, University of Pennsylvania center for bioethics director, describes importance of written instructions to aid courts and doctors in making best decision for patient and family; differences between living wills and health care proxies discussed; photos (M)
docs.snippet: The case of Terri Schiavo may help motivate people to adopt advance directives like living wills.

docs.lead_paragraph: I can't understand why we still don't have a national initiative to control what is fast emerging as the most serious and costly health problem in America: excess weight. Are our schools, our parents, our national leaders blind to what is happening -- a health crisis that looms even larger than our former and current smoking habits? Just look at the numbers, so graphically described in an eye-opening new book, ''Diabesity: The Obesity-Diabetes Epidemic That Threatens America -- and What We Must Do to Stop It'' (Bantam), by Dr. Francine R. Kaufman, a pediatric endocrinologist, the director of the diabetes clinic at Children's Hospital Los Angeles and a past president of the American Diabetes Association.

headline.main: 'Diabesity,' a Crisis in an Expanding Country

docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column discusses need for initiative to control national health crisis involving Type 2 diabetes; Dr Francine R Kaufman, Children's Hospital Los Angeles diabetes clinic director and pediatric endocrinologist, book Diabesity: The Obesity Diabetes Epidemic That Threatens America, notes virtual non-existence of type 2 in children prior to 1993; asserts that widespread changes are necessary to help young people lead healthy lives; estimated 18.2 million Americans have diabetes, which ranks first nationally in direct health care costs; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: What is the reason for the runaway epidemic of diabetes? Being overweight or obese, especially with the accumulation of large amounts of body fat around the abdomen.

docs.lead_paragraph: It is widely known that people who sleep wearing contract lenses are taking a risk that they could end up with a serious infection. But a newer generation of contact lenses has a much lower risk, a new study finds, and researchers studying them suggest that people who insist on wearing contacts in their sleep should use them. The study, led by Dr. Philip B. Morgan of the University of Manchester in England, appears in The British Journal of Ophthalmology.
docs.abstract: Dr Philip B Morgan of University of Mancchester leads study on impact of sleeping with contact lens still in eyes; study, which is published in British Journal of Ophtalmology, finds that wearing any contact lens to bed increases risk of infection, but lens made from silicone hydrogel appear to be less harmful to eye health (S)
docs.snippet: A newer generation of contact lenses has a much lower risk, a new study finds, and researchers studying them suggest that people who insist on wearing contacts in their sleep should use them.

docs.lead_paragraph: Kathleen Young had no reason to believe she was anything but healthy. She led a hectic life, running a tree-trimming business with her husband, studying to become a nurse and bringing up three daughters, ages 10, 12 and 13, in Raymore, Mo. But in an instant last September, everything changed. While working out at the gym, Mrs. Young, 41, suddenly went blind in her left eye. Minutes later, her head began to pound. The diagnosis, after an M.R.I. and other tests, was almost beyond comprehension: a rare disease had created blockages in arteries deep inside her skull, cutting off blood flow to part of her brain and causing a stroke, which had partly blinded her.

headline.main: Out of Nowhere, a Devastating Tangle in the Brain

docs.abstract: Moyamoya disease, rare disease that blocks arteries in brain and causes strokes and brain function damage, is incurable, but treatable through surgery; Dr Gary Steinberg, Stanford University Medical Center head of neurosurgery who has operated on 130 moyamoya patients, holds disease is probably more common than thought; surgery on patient Kathleen Young described; over 95 percent of patients who receive surgical treatment never experience another stroke; photos (L)
docs.snippet: As surgeons learn more, a rare but deadly brain disorder called moyamoya disease has slowly become treatable.

docs.lead_paragraph: A quick look at a man's waistband may provide a big clue about his risk for diabetes. In fact, researchers report, the relationship seemed to be an even better gauge than body mass index, a measure of height and weight. The study, led by Dr. Youfa Wang, appears in the current American Journal of Clinical Nutrition.

headline.main: For Men, a Belt Test for Diabetes

docs.abstract: Dr Youfa Wang leads research that shows large waist measurement to be indicator of diabetes risk in men; study, which is published in American Journal of Clinical Nutrition and derived from data taken by Harvard Health Professionals Follow-Up Study, suggests that maximum waist size listed in federal guideline be lowered from current 40 inches; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: A quick look at a man's waistband may provide a big clue about his risk for diabetes.

docs.lead_paragraph: Days after the tsunami struck South Asia, American mental health workers flew to Sri Lanka to offer counseling services to grief-stricken victims. ''Psychological scarring needs to be dealt with as quickly as possible,'' one psychologist told The Washington Post in January. ''The longer we wait, the more danger.'' Sri Lankan health officials saw things slightly differently. They discouraged aid agencies that offered to send counselors to their country.

headline.main: Bread and Shelter, Yes. Psychiatrists, No.

docs.abstract: Often when natural or man-made disaster strikes region, many foreign aid groups rush to help those individuals who have been traumatized and up-rooted; Dr Sally Satel, psychiatrist and co-author of book One Nation Under Therapy: How the Helping Culture Is Eroding Self-Reliance, explains why she feels western approach to therapeutic aid can be detrimental to those suffering from natural disaster or other trauma; describes differences in culture and experience and gives examples of how integrated aid between foreign groups and locals can work best; photo (M)
docs.snippet: Days after the tsunami struck South Asia, American mental health workers flew to Sri Lanka to offer counseling services to grief-stricken victims.    ''Psychological scarring needs to be dealt with as quickly as possible,'' one psychologist told The...

docs.lead_paragraph: Many doctors believe that sugar pills are likely to be effective for patients with chronic fatigue syndrome, trusting that a placebo will help relieve the mental and physical exhaustion that characterize the illness. But a new study has found that people who have the syndrome respond at a lower rate to placebos than patients with other diseases. The paper was published in the March-April issue of Psychosomatic Medicine.

headline.main: For Chronic Fatigue, Placebos Fail the Test

docs.abstract: Placebo treatments, which have been found to be moderately effective in treating variety of illnesses, are found to be effective only 19.6 percent of time for people with chronic fatigue syndrome; Dr Hyong Jin Cho, King's College London psychiatry professor who led placebo study published in Psychosomatic Medicine, suggests that poor patient-doctor relationships could be impeding effective use of placebo; Centers for Disease Control and Prevention estimates 500,000 Americans suffer from chronic fatigue syndrome (M)
docs.snippet: A new study has found that people who have the syndrome respond at a lower rate to placebos than patients with other diseases.

keywords.name: organizations
keywords.value: CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION

docs.lead_paragraph: People with high levels of cholesterol do better on a variety of tests measuring mental ability, researchers from Boston University have found. The study, led by Dr. Penelope K. Elias, appeared in the January/February issue of Psychosomatic Medicine. The findings grow out of information compiled by the long-term Framingham Heart Study, and are based on the medical histories of 789 men and 1,105 women over about 18 years.
docs.abstract: Dr Penelope K Elias, Boston University researcher, leads study on link between mental ability and high cholesterol; findings, published in journal Psychosomatic Medicine and derived from information compiled by Framingham Heart Study, suggest high cholesterol is associated with higher mental skills, such as memory and abstract reasoning; drawing (S)
docs.snippet: People with high levels of cholesterol do better on a variety of tests measuring mental ability, researchers from Boston University have found.
